name: TheAtlantic
text: In our latest "Behind the Byline" feature, @edyong209 shares what it's like covering the coronavirus pandemic, how he got his journalism start, and the books and shows he's enjoying. https://t.co/HqE9nL9LFt

name: TheAtlantic
text: After Reddit published a letter in support of Black Lives Matter, its own users called the company out for hypocrisy. Now, they’re asking for real change on a site that has been famous for racism for years, @kait_tiffany reports. https://t.co/jx1SXJZIUO

name: TheAtlantic
text: Hollywood has made many Vietnam War stories over the past 50 years, but very few have dug into the experiences of black servicemen in that conflict. Spike Lee's "Da 5 Bloods"—out on Netflix—is a masterful film that changes that, @davidlsims writes: https://t.co/M80cYKRC3K

name: TheAtlantic
text: The big tech companies are eager to help the government respond to the pandemic. What’s in it for them? @FranklinFoer asks. https://t.co/u1sRDElnz4

name: TheAtlantic
text: Rhythmic gymnastics on a British seashore, anti-racism protests across the United States, the funeral procession of George Floyd in Houston, a wildfire in California, idled elephants in Thailand, and much more—via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/Kx3fGltMmN

name: TheAtlantic
text: "If the first brick signals the beginning of a moral holiday for looters, the first thwack of a truncheon signals a moral holiday for cops primed to react to the unknown with fear and loathing," @gcaw writes: https://t.co/gBwqwF6EbE

name: TheAtlantic
text: Americans seem antsy to restart their lives, but this pandemic isn’t over. In the meantime: Here’s what to watch, read, and listen to this weekend. The latest Atlantic Daily, from @mimbsy: https://t.co/9AmTzNYFpi

name: TheAtlantic
text: The TV show “Cops” was a simulacrum of American police work, polished and cut and spliced into a hollow replica. @sophieGG on the long-running reality series that got canceled this week: https://t.co/dA0z5Vnzfv

name: TheAtlantic
text: The early days of the pandemic were characterized by a longing for “normal” life. @sista_theology argues that there is no going back to “normal”—and that the Black Lives Matter protests are a promising sign that society is starting to look forward instead: https://t.co/tTJbi991en

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I am a scientist who, for the past nine weeks, has been studying the respiratory virus that is disproportionately killing people who look like me," @agladdenyoung writes: https://t.co/db2wY9zwJz

name: TheAtlantic
text: Evidence of a looming coronavirus pandemic was building for years, but scientists who study the virus had struggled to get funding to convince Americans of the risk, Charles Schmidt writes. https://t.co/g0aBndjeUH

name: TheAtlantic
text: One biscuit tells a billion stories. @aliaallana tracks India's lockdown through the country's favorite comfort food: https://t.co/SxNVdlrQcb

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Openly lawless behavior by police officers thrives on their belief that they have a license to be brutal and that no one will hold them accountable for their actions," @KPNatsFan writes: https://t.co/73GV1OKjJX

name: TheAtlantic
text: America owes its existence, at least in part, to conspiracy thinking. This timeline from our special project “Shadowland” goes back to the earliest days of conspiracy thinking to show how they’ve captured the American mind for centuries. https://t.co/o6WplfC1VY
